articles.headline: Facebook Employees Stage Virtual Walkout to Protest Trump Posts
articles.snippet: While Twitter started labeling some of the president’s inflammatory messages, Facebook’s chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, has said his company should leave them alone.
articles.abstract: While Twitter started labeling some of the president’s inflammatory messages, Facebook’s chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, has said his company should leave them alone.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Hundreds of Facebook employees, in rare public criticism on Monday of their own company, protested executives’ decision not to do anything about inflammatory posts that President Trump had placed on the giant social media platform over the past week.
articles.byline: By Sheera Frenkel, Mike Isaac, Cecilia Kang and Gabriel J.X. Dance

articles.headline: As Trump Calls Protesters ‘Terrorists,’ Tear Gas Clears a Path for His Walk to a Church
articles.snippet: In a Rose Garden speech shaded with anger, President Trump threatened to send the American military to states where governors could not bring under control the protests over police brutality.
articles.abstract: In a Rose Garden speech shaded with anger, President Trump threatened to send the American military to states where governors could not bring under control the protests over police brutality.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Monday angrily denounced the demonstrators who have used violence to call attention to the deaths of black men killed by the police as “organizers” of terrorism, and threatened to send the American military to states where governors could not bring the protests under control.
articles.byline: By Katie Rogers, Jonathan Martin and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Retailers, Battered by Pandemic, Now Confront Protests
articles.snippet: Even as major chains boarded up stores and halted operations, they largely sought to convey empathy for demonstrators and did not condemn the damage to their businesses.
articles.abstract: Even as major chains boarded up stores and halted operations, they largely sought to convey empathy for demonstrators and did not condemn the damage to their businesses.
articles.lead_paragraph: People smashed the front doors of a Walmart in Peoria, Ill. They ransacked an Apple store in Philadelphia and broke the windows at Nordstrom’s flagship in Seattle, its hometown, while throwing merchandise into the crowds outside.
articles.byline: By Sapna Maheshwari and Michael Corkery

articles.headline: Black Workers, Already Lagging, Face Big Economic Risks
articles.snippet: Black employment rates are plummeting, and the evolving wealth and income hit could fall on the shoulders of those ill-equipped to bear it.

articles.headline: After George Floyd’s Death, Toll Rises in Protests Across the Country
articles.snippet: At least five people have died in unrest over the death of Mr. Floyd. Injuries have been numerous, and millions of dollars in damage to property has occurred.
articles.abstract: At least five people have died in unrest over the death of Mr. Floyd. Injuries have been numerous, and millions of dollars in damage to property has occurred.
articles.lead_paragraph: Scores of American cities were on edge on Monday night as protesters faced off with the police for a seventh straight night since the death of George Floyd at the hands of the Minneapolis police. Curfews were ordered in New York City and throughout the country in an effort to stem the toll of deaths, injuries and vandalism that have accompanied demonstrations that grew violent.
articles.byline: By Campbell Robertson, Rick Rojas and Kate Taylor

articles.headline: Joe Biden Laces Into Trump for Fanning ‘Flames of Hate’
articles.snippet: In a speech in Philadelphia, Mr. Biden assailed the president’s handling of the protests over police brutality and racial justice, declaring that he had “turned this country into a battlefield.”
articles.abstract: In a speech in Philadelphia, Mr. Biden assailed the president’s handling of the protests over police brutality and racial justice, declaring that he had “turned this country into a battlefield.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Tuesday excoriated President Trump’s stewardship of a nation convulsed in crisis over racism and police brutality, likening Mr. Trump’s language to that of Southern racists of the 1960s while also warning Americans that “we cannot let our rage consume us.”
